title: Foundation Year R Programming
text:
Preface
This book is a companion to the Royal Holloway, University of London Foundation Year Statistics Course for Biological Sciences.

See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.

title: 1Â  Introduction to R programming and RStudio
text:
1.1 R
R is a programming language that is widely used for statistical analysis and other data science applications. It is free and open source. Competing statistical software usually requires expensive subscriptions. Using R programming, you can not only run statistical analysis, but you can also create plots, maps, and even produce PDF and HTML reports.

title: 1Â  Introduction to R programming and RStudio
text:
1.2 RStudio
Like other programming languages, R can be run from the terminal (Mac) or command line (PC). However, running code from the command line can be quite difficult. In this course we will be using RStudio to run R. RStudio is a graphical user interface (GUI). A GUI makes it easier for you, the user, to write code, input data, and visualise results.

title: 1Â  Introduction to R programming and RStudio
text:
1.3 Installing R and RStudio
The first step is to download and install R. Navigate to the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) and select the correct download link for your system (Windows, Mac, orâ€¦Linux?).
You will need to download and install RStudio. Navigate to the (Posit website)[https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/] to install the desktop version of RStudio.

title: 1Â  Introduction to R programming and RStudio
text:
1.4 Tour of RStudio
The RStudio window is divided into a number of panes.

1.4.1 Console, Terminal, Background Jobs
By default, the bottom left pane will contain tabs Console, Terminal, and Background Jobs.
You will mostly be using the console tab. This is where your code will be executed and where you will see results from statistical tests. You can also type code here to be executed.






Navigating history of the console



You can press arrow keys â†‘ and â†“ to go backward and forward through the history of code that was executed. This is useful for quickly going back to fix an error in code.




1.4.2 Environment, History, Connections, Build, Tutorial
By default, the top-right pane has tabs Environment, History, Connections, Build, and Tutorial. You will mostly use the environment tab. This is where data you import or variables you define will appear.






Viewing things in the environment



You can click on items that are in the environment to view them in an Excel-like viewer. This is useful for scrolling through data and looking at data in an easy-to-view manner.




1.4.3 Files, Plots, Packages, Help, Viewer, Presentation
By default, the bottom right pane will have tabs for Files, Plots, Packages, Help, Viewer, and Presentation. You will spend most of your time in the Plots pane as this is where plots will appear when you generate plots.


1.4.4 Source
By default, the top left pane that will appear when you create a new R script is called the â€œSourceâ€ pane. This is where you will write script that can be executed in the console.

title: Week 1 - Introduction to R programming and RStudio
text:
Writing your first R script
While you can write and execute code directly in the console, when you are doing analyses I strongly encourage you to ğŸ‘ write ğŸ‘ a ğŸ‘ script! ğŸ‘
A script is just a text file with a .R extension (the file name ends in â€œ.Râ€) which tells your computer to run the commands using the R programming language installed on your computer. Writing a script allows you to keep your analysis and thoughts organised. It also allows you to reproduce your analysis easily. You can take the scripts you create and
To create a new script, navigate to File > New File > R Script
You can also use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + â‡§ Shift + N on Windows or âŒ˜ + â‡§ Shift + N on Mac.

str(1)

 num 1

title: Week 2 - Averages, standard deviation, and standard error
text:
Mean
As you know, the mean (or average) is the sum of a group of numbers divided by the number of individual numbers.
There are a few base R functions that we can use to calculate the mean.
To calculate a mean, first we add up all the values that we are interested in using the sum() function.
Here, we will use the rivers dataset which is included in your installation of R. rivers is a predefined dataset and you can find out more about it by typing ?rivers in the console. rivers is a vector which is a list of items that all have the same type (i.e.Â list of numbers, list of strings, etc.)
First, we add up all the elements of the vector rivers by using the function sum()

sum(rivers)

We can assign this value to a variable by using

title: Week 1 - Introduction to R programming and RStudio
text:
Writing and executing code
In the console, you can write and execute code. You can do simple mathematical operations. Try to do a couple now. Another important thing to do is assigning variables. By convention, in R variables are mostly assigned using the leftward operator and it is constructed by typing a less-than sign followed by a hyphen (<-).

x <- 5
x*2

[1] 10

x-11

[1] -6

title: What is R?
text:
R programming


â€œlanguage and environment for statistical computing and graphicsâ€ - https://www.r-project.org/about.html




free and open source




import data, data exploration, statistical analysis, graphical representation, report creation





Learning R has its ups and downs





Success in R is enabled by support from lots of people





Some people really really like R

title: What is R?
text:
R Studio

Writing code

Maths
You can do simple math in the console.


1 + 1

[1] 2




You can use pi as well as other more complex arithmetic.


4*pi

[1] 12.56637





10^2

[1] 100





Assigning variables
By convention, variables are assigned using <-

x <- 5



x

[1] 5





x*2

[1] 10









Navigating history of the console



You can press arrow keys â†‘ and â†“ to go backward and forward through the history of code that was executed. This is useful for quickly going back to fix an error in code.





We use <- instead of = by convention although both have the same function.




Types of variables



source: https://sydney-informatics-hub.github.io/lessonbmc/02-BMC_R_Day1_B/index.html




Creating a script
A script is a file containing text, written in the R programming language, which can be executed in R.
File -> New File -> R Script


Stay organised (logical flow)




Repeat the same analysis with new data




Share code with others









Executing your script



Click on a line in your script and press Ctrl + â†µ Return to execute your script line-by-line.

title: What is R?
text:
Writing code

Creating vectors
A vector is simply a list of items that are all the same type.
The function c() combines values to a vector (list).
Functions follow the pattern function_name(argument/s).

x <- c(1,4,5.8) # I am assigning my favourite numbers to the variable "x"



x*2             # Multiply each number by 2

[1]  2.0  8.0 11.6









Commenting on code



Everything to the right of the hashtag (#) is considered a â€œcommentâ€ and is not interpreted as R code.

title: What is R?
text:
Writing code

Creating vectors

x <- c("Windsor", "Davison", "Founder's", "Bourne", "The Hub")
x

[1] "Windsor"   "Davison"   "Founder's" "Bourne"    "The Hub"  




x*2

Error in x * 2: non-numeric argument to binary operator

title: What is R?
text:
Writing code

Whatâ€™s my variable?
We can find out the structure of a variable or dataframe is is by using the function str()

x <- c(1,4,5.8) # I am assigning my favorite numbers to the variable "x"
str(x)

 num [1:3] 1 4 5.8




y <- "fish"
str(y)

 chr "fish"

title: What is R?
text:
Base R and packages

R comes with various functions, packages, and datasets â€œbaked inâ€
c(), str(), sqrt(), log(), etc.
Built-in datasets
You can get help within R Studio by typing a question mark before a function, package, or dataset (i.e.Â ?str())

title: What is R?
text:
Base R and packages

Packages

packages are created by R users to expand functionality of R
statistical packages, graphical packages, unique datasets, etc.

title: What is R?
text:
Base R and packages
We will use many datasets from the datasets package built into R.
One such dataset is called mtcars.
